channel.title: SDS 348 Final Project
channel.description: Recent content on SDS 348 Final Project

item.title: How python is used in Comp Bio
item.description: Throughout the semester, we had 2 big projects where we used R studio to analyze data. Both were very interesting and challenging projects to do. As the semester is coming to an end, the last concept that we learned about was Python. Python is a very useful language due to its productivity and simple programming syntax. In this post, I would like to demonstrate some of the skill that I have been working on.

item.title: Project 1 (F)
item.description: getwd() ## [1] "/stor/home/jj37257/website/content/project" work_dir <- "/stor/home/jj37257/website/content/project" Marriage <- read.csv("Marriage.csv") weather <- read.csv("2530921.csv") library(dplyr) library(ggridges) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2) library(kableExtra) library(tibble) library(cluster) ## The data sets that I have chosen for this project were ## marriage and weather data from Mobile County, Alabama. I ## thought that these two data could go together when you ## think about how many people decide to have their ceremony ## based on the weather.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: ##Introduction: work_dir <-"/stor/home/jj37257/website/content/project" affair <- read.csv("Affairs.csv") affair$X <- NULL This is the ‘affairs’ dataset, which is a dataset containing information on infidelity, known as Fair’s Affairs. The data was attained using cross-section from a survey conducted by Psychology Today in 1969. It contains the following variables: number of affairs, the person’s gender and age,the number of years they were married, number of children they have,their religiousness, education level, occupation, and their rating of marriage.
